question: It's warmer than I thought.
answer: You want to go to a movie tonight?

question: I thought your mom's coming up?
answer: So?

question: My parents are having friends from college over. They're really nice... They have this gorgeous son who wants to be a forest ranger.
answer: Can I come? I'll start a fire... Hello, beautiful boy. Stop... Will you stop! Show-off.

question: Hello?
answer: It's me.

question: Hi.
answer: Hi.

question: So, what, uh, what train are you taking?
answer: I should be in by two.

question: Okay. You want me to pick you up?
answer: Sure... What's Grace up to?

question: Riding with Judith.
answer: I'm sorry about last night. I shouldn't have brought it up over the phone.

question: That's okay. We have to talk about it and we're not always in the same place ... so... I just have to get used to it. What do you want to do about dinner?
answer: I don't know. We'll figure it out.

question: Okay. We'll see you later then.
answer: Yeah. Bye. DON! My love, how are you? Did you hear about Fiske?... No, suing is too civilized. Can't we get your friend at Le Cirque to serve him a fatal piece of poached salmon?... Ha, ha... That's even better...

question: ...Oh, come on! You think the same thing!
answer: I just could never say it!

question: Do you want to go around by the old road?
answer: Why don't we just cut through the woods?

question: You want to go down or stay along the river?
answer: We already did the river. Let's go down and across the old bridge. We can circle back.

question: ... So what did you say to her? All right, all right, all right... Kevin, good job. Write the interview. If I don't like it, you may have to sleep with her for a follow-up! Now... I'm thinking about another fashion designer spread... Who's news out there? Quiet... Quiet! David?
answer: Who's there?

question: Everyone. Working overtime. Just for you.
answer: Did you speak to Farlow?

question: Yes. We're suing.
answer: Is that absolutely necessary? It'll just make it a bigger story.

question: David, he signed an agreement that he wouldn't talk to the press and he's libeled me by saying I faked the figures. You're not going soft on me, are you?
answer: Well, I suppose we could use another good public feud...

question: "... I said it--"
answer: "... and I said that"...

question: No, wait, it just goes... "he said he liked to do-"...
answer: What was -- Grace!

question: JUDITH!
answer: GRAAACE!

question: PILGRIM, COME ON! MOVE! Jude, you okay?
answer: I'm okay... I'm okay.

question: Yeah?... Hi. I made the 1:00 so... WHAT!?
answer: Judith's dead.

question: What about Grace?
answer: She was in pretty bad shape. They've done a C.A.T. Scan -- she has some hemorrhaging...

question: Where is she now? Surgery! For what-?
answer: Annie, her leg was shattered -- what they call the distal epi.. epi.. They have to take the leg off.

question: Which leg?
answer: What difference does it make?

question: That bag's almost empty.
answer: No, it's got a little left. They'll be in to change it.

question: Robert, you leave it up these people...! Excuse me, my daughter needs a new I'd like it taken care of now please. You have to keep on top of these people or else they just sit on their --
answer: I'm sorry.

question: Tch. What are you --
answer: Thank you.

question: Annie, it's Liz. How's Grace?
answer: Her leg was shattered so they had to, uh... remove it. She had some bleeding but it's under control.

question: Oh God, Annie, I'm so sorry. I... I know you're being hit with a low now, I don't want to take too much of your time but I have to talk to you about Pilgrim. It's not good. I've never seen an animal with these injuries still breathing. I know this is difficult to hear right now I'd like your permission to put him down. It's the really best thing we can do for --
answer: Wait, uh, I, I don't understand. Start again -- He's alive...

question: Yes, but he's in a tremendous pain...
answer: Well, of course, right...

question: Liz, listen, the Doctor's here and I just can't, uh... talk now... so --
answer: I understand, but Annie, please...

question: - See, what you can do for him --...
answer: Annie, no matter what I do, this horse will never be the same.

question: ... I just don't know right now! Do whatever you can and when Grace is --
answer: It isn't right to make him suffer...

question: And I can say the same thing about my daughter! But she is suffering! Can you solve that problem! I can't deal with this now, Liz! If you need a yes or no right now, then no -- don't do it! Not until I know Grace is all right. Now, please! Just do what you can. Okay? Please.
answer: All right...

question: What did he say?
answer: Nothing new. He's just going off duty.

question: I'm going to get all the nurses' names... It's good to know all their names. I should go get some of her things.
answer: No, let me go.

question: No, I'll go. You stay... In case she wakes up.
answer: I saw Judith's parents while you were at the apartment... I wanted to say something... But I... I was so relieved that Grace was still... that it wasn't our daughter.

question: We're very lucky.
answer: The funeral's on Friday. Oh, uh, I meant to tell you... Alex brought that fabric over...

question: Okay.
answer: It's on the table by the phone. I didn't know what to tell him... ... Whether or not we were... ... if we still we're thinking of redoing the couch. ... And uh... Mario called about moving the wisteria?

question: Oh. Right. I'll call him. "SHE'S LOVES THE THEATRE BUT NEVER COMES
answer: "She loves the free..." "... FRESH, WIND IN HER HAIR... LIFE

question: Sing it to me, Frankie!
answer: How's my pregnant chick!

question: You can hardly get your arms around me. How depressing. You're so early.
answer: I had to excuse myself from a meeting. It's ridiculous. I kept thinking about the baby... you... and, I swear, I was going to start bawling right into my briefs.

question: Aw... that's so sweet.
answer: I love you.

question: Do you? Do you really?
answer: Hi, sweetheart...

question: Dad! I can do it, OK?!
answer: OK, OK.

question: You all go ahead. I'll be up by Christmas.
answer: Do you want something else, honey? We order something else?

question: NO!
answer: Do you want any help? Dad'll pick you up today, all right?

question: Okay.
answer: You'll be fine. I don't care what he told you! The man's a liar! The man's an actor, for Christ's sake. They're all liars! They'll say anything to get a cover...

question: It's too hard.
answer: Oh, honey... What happened?

question: Doesn't matter. I... I don't want to come back, that's all.
answer: Oh. Well, what are you going to do? You have to go to school, honey. I mean, what --

question: I'm not coming back! That's it! I want to go home!
answer: Grace, listen to me. Your body is just healing. You have to give the rest of you time as well...

question: Is that your version of a pep talk?
answer: You are not staying home all day feeling sorry for yourself. You're going to get up and you're going to figure this out.

question: Fine!
answer: It's still early. What's your next class?

question: I'm fine.
answer: Well, come on. He's out back now... Mind how you go. It's pretty muddy back there.

question: Why is he in the back? Why isn't he in the barn with the other horses?
answer: Well, Grace, you see... Pilgrim just... isn't the same horse he used to be. As a matter of fact, maybe now's not the best time to --

question: I really want to see him. Hello, beautiful boy...
answer: You should have told her, Annie. I tried to explain to you how bad it was... I guess you had to see it. But, there's nothing to be done. This animal's beyond help. Annie, can I have your permission now to put him down?

question: Hey, darlin'.
answer: Hey, Rona. Sorry I'm late.

question: I wouldn't know what to do if you were on time.
answer: You're looking fit.

question: Fit? You want to check my teeth. Good crowd today. I think you'll have some fun. You going to stay for dinner?
answer: If it's not too much trouble, I thought I might.

question: Kind of trouble I'm in the mood for.
answer: Oh-oh... Maybe I better get back in the truck. ... It's always kind of interesting to hear the horse's side of the story... Now if he was cranky or lazy, like you say he is, we'd be seeing his tail twitching there and his ears back, maybe. But this isn't a cranky horse, it's a scared horse. You see how braced he is up around the neck back there. He just doesn't know which way to turn... You see how he keeps pointing his hindquarters in at me? Well, I'd guess the reason he seems reluctant to move out is because when he does, he gets in trouble for it. Well, I'm sure that's what you think but that's not what I'm seeing. You may think you're asking for a lope, but your body may be saying something else altogether. You might be putting too many conditions on him. For instance, you might be saying "GO, but, hey, don't go too fast." He can tell that from the way you feel. Your body can't lie. You ever give him a kick to make him move out? And then he goes and you feel like he's going too fast, so you yank him back? And next thing you know, he's bucking. Well, if someone told you to go, stop, go, stop -- you'd buck too. It's a dance, see... Somebody has to lead and somebody has to follow. I want him to get so he can leave real soft. He's getting the idea now. He's not all braced up and tense like he was at the start. He's finding out it's okay. You see that? He's getting better already. Pretty soon, if you work at it, you'll be able to make all these transitions easy on a loose rein. Yeah, and pigs'll fly. He's going to be okay -- so long as you don't go yanking on him. Look, the truth is it's all about self- preservation. These animals. ... well, they just have such big hearts, you know? There's nothing they want more than to do what you want them to do. But when the messages get all confused, the only thing they know to do is try and save themselves... Now, why don't you go saddle up and see what happens. They won't ever hold a thing against you. They're the most forgiving creatures God ever made. Okay, who's next? Now God has another idea entirely with the mule.

question: Oh-oh... Maybe I better get back in the truck. ... It's always kind of interesting to hear the horse's side of the story... Now if he was cranky or lazy, like you say he is, we'd be seeing his tail twitching there and his ears back, maybe. But this isn't a cranky horse, it's a scared horse. You see how braced he is up around the neck back there. He just doesn't know which way to turn... You see how he keeps pointing his hindquarters in at me? Well, I'd guess the reason he seems reluctant to move out is because when he does, he gets in trouble for it. Well, I'm sure that's what you think but that's not what I'm seeing. You may think you're asking for a lope, but your body may be saying something else altogether. You might be putting too many conditions on him. For instance, you might be saying "GO, but, hey, don't go too fast." He can tell that from the way you feel. Your body can't lie. You ever give him a kick to make him move out? And then he goes and you feel like he's going too fast, so you yank him back? And next thing you know, he's bucking. Well, if someone told you to go, stop, go, stop -- you'd buck too. It's a dance, see... Somebody has to lead and somebody has to follow. I want him to get so he can leave real soft. He's getting the idea now. He's not all braced up and tense like he was at the start. He's finding out it's okay. You see that? He's getting better already. Pretty soon, if you work at it, you'll be able to make all these transitions easy on a loose rein. Yeah, and pigs'll fly. He's going to be okay -- so long as you don't go yanking on him. Look, the truth is it's all about self- preservation. These animals. ... well, they just have such big hearts, you know? There's nothing they want more than to do what you want them to do. But when the messages get all confused, the only thing they know to do is try and save themselves... Now, why don't you go saddle up and see what happens. They won't ever hold a thing against you. They're the most forgiving creatures God ever made. Okay, who's next? Now God has another idea entirely with the mule.
answer: Excuse me. Hi. I'm Dale. I just wanted to -- I can't get over the way he felt under me after you'd finish with him. Everything had just, I don't know, freed up or something.

question: Well, that'll happen.
answer: Where did you learn all this stuff?

question: What stuff is that?
answer: About horses? I'd love to learn more about it myself. Do you offer any private lessons for riders?

question: Well... Dale... you know, a lot of this stuff... it just... nuts and bolts.
answer: What do you mean?

question: Well, if the rider's nuts, the horse bolts. That's the whole lesson right there. You have a good day now... Just... keep on freeing yourself up.
answer: Oh I clear forget. You had a call from some woman in New York. She sounded pretty wound up.

question: I don't any woman in New York. But from what I hear, most of them are wound up.
answer: The number's by the phone. What are you looking at, young man?

question: How long were you married?
answer: Long enough.

question: You ever miss it?
answer: Does a horse miss a saddle?

question: Sometimes.
answer: Well as a matter of fact, I don't... most of the time.

question: You know, Rona, we weren't all that good together even when we were good together.
answer: Honey... I was always good.

question: You know it's perfectly shot, it's perfectly cropped, it's perfectly laid out and I'm so bloody bored, I'd rather buy a Motor Racing magazine -- Start over. Uh, would you all excuse me a moment? This is Annie MacLean.
answer: Yeah. Hello. This is Tom Booker. I got a message you called.

question: Oh! Yes. Thank you for calling back. Uh, all right, let me try to explain my situation as briefly as possible... You see, my daughter had an accident with her horse... They were both injured and she, my daughter, she hasn't been able to... fully... uh... It was an extremely traumatic experience... and uh... I went on the Internet and found this article about you... It says you're a Horse Whisperer, that you... you help people with horse problems. And you have quite a success rate when it comes to traumatized --
answer: Well, see, truth is, ma'am, I help horses with people's problems.

question: Well, you know, however you want to put it -- I got your information from the publisher of the article. I called Montana and your sister-in-law, I think, gave me this number. I'm been hot on your trail you could say because I was hoping you'd consider coming to New York and taking a look at my daughter's horse and possibly --
answer: Ma'am, I'm very sorry about your problems and I appreciate what your daughter must be going through, but I'm afraid you've misunderstood whatever it is you read. I don't do that sort of thing.

question: Well, if you could just come for the day. New York's only a few hours by plane, I'd have you home by dinner...
answer: Look, even if it was nearer, that's just not what I do. I give clinics. And I'm not even doing them for a while. I'm heading back to Montana right now. I got a ranch to take care of...

question: I'll pay you for your fare. I'll send you to Montana first class.
answer: Ma'am, first class to Montana is a waste of good money. Now, am I being too polite here or when I say NO in Utah, does that mean YES in New York City? I, I don't mean to sound insensitive. I understand your situation. But there's nothing I can do. You just called the wrong person, that's all. I hear there are a bunch of therapists in New York. Maybe you should call one of them.

question: Mr. Booker, if I could just ex --
answer: I am very sorry, ma'am. Goodbye now.

question: Grace? Grace, it's mom. Grace. What are you doing?
answer: I can't find that charm Daddy gave me from India.

question: I brought it to you in the hospital.
answer: No, you didn't.

question: Grace, I put it on the table near your --
answer: Doesn't matter.

question: Have you decided about Pilgrim?
answer: What about him?

question: Well... how you feel all right about telling Liz to put him down...
answer: I think we should. It's not fair to let him suffer. He's not much use anymore. He'd hate living like that.

question: I think that's... very compassionate and... mature way of looking at it.
answer: Mom?

question: Yeah?
answer: Maybe they should put me down too.

question: What?
answer: I mean, I'm not much use anymore. Why can't they be compassionate to me?

question: How was the dinner?
answer: All our "favorite" people were there saying all their "favorite" things about their "favorite" subjects. I thought to myself, we've been friends with these people almost twenty years and nobody knows anybody. We're so afraid we won't like each other and have nobody go to dinners with.

question: Why did you go?
answer: They're still our friends, Annie. It's nothing serious. You kid about them all the time... And I could tell Paul really appreciated me being there. Did you get a hold of that horse guy?

question: Yeah.
answer: What did he say?

question: No.
answer: I was thinking... Maybe we should think about the three of us going someplace warm... Remember that house we rented in Bermuda... The pink one with the -- Shit. What was I saying?

question: About us going someplace warm... Someplace Grace'll have to wear shorts or bathing suits or summer dresses... Robert, I want to take Pilgrim out to Mr. Booker. Drive him out to Montana... With Grace.
answer: I don't understand. You just said he said no.

question: He did, but... I think I can change his mind.
answer: That's the craziest thing I ever heard. Absolutely not.

question: Robert, Grace isn't adjusting to school. And she can't sit in this apartment all day... I think it would be good for her.
answer: NO! What are you -- you're serious about this?

question: I've called Liz. They can set me up with a trailer for Pilgrim. I thought we'd stay at motels along the way...
answer: You've already made arrangements!?

question: No. I was just researching. Calm down.
answer: I come home and you tell me we're going to drive a psychotic horse to Montana! I can't just pick up and leave...

question: I'm not asking you to. I'll do it.
answer: You want to do this by yourself? How? You can't take care of Pilgrim all the --

question: He'll be sedated. I know horses, Robert. I'm the one who taught Grace how to ride.
answer: What... Bo-... What about the magazine?

question: I'm in charge. I went back very soon after the accident. They didn't expect me for a couple of months. I'll just take that time now... I can still oversee things from Montana... Take my fax... My computer...
answer: No. It's, uh... No, I really don't think it's a good idea

question: Why?!
answer: Her psychiatrist... said... she needs security now... stability...

question: I can't say he's been all that effective with her.
answer: Are you a psychiatrist? He said it takes time.

question: I don't care what he says! We have to do something, Robert! I can't sit here and trust everything's going to work out just by pretending it will.
answer: I'm not pretending anything!

question: What?
answer: I thought... well, ever since the accident, I just thought we... I really wish I could understand why you think this is so necessary.

question: Robert, we're losing her. We're losing her. I don't care what the doctors say. The truth is, they don't know anymore than we do -- less, when it comes to Grace... This may not sound sensible or... logical, but nobody's suggesting anything better. I can't explain it, Robert. I just have this feeling... this annoying... bloody feeling that if... if, somehow, Pilgrim can be made all right... then so can Grace. I just know it!
answer: What if she doesn't want to go?

question: She will if you think she should.
answer: And you think it's best if I don't come.

question: Maybe we should give him another sedative.
answer: Problem is, there aren't many volunteers. He's already had enough to sink a battleship. You have a pin, just in case?

question: Of course not.
answer: Probably best. You may want to shoot yourself half way to Ohio.

question: You want to take your bath? We have to get up early tomorrow. You may not have enough time to --
answer: Fine -- I'll take my bath.

question: No, I don't mean you have to. It's just that we may not have enough --
answer: -- enough time tomorrow. I know.

question: Look, if you want to take it in the morning, that's fine.
answer: I don't care.

question: What, sweetheart? What? It's sleeping in a strange bed, that's all. Happens sometimes. It's Ok. It's OK. Okay, listen -- let's do this. When I get to the next motel, I'll see if they have a fax. If not, I'll call you tomorrow to -- Uh Lucy, look, I have to go. OK... Later. Grace! GRACE! Would you like to put your music on up here?
answer: Whatever you want.

question: Fine!
answer: Fine.

question: Fine! "Whatever you want!" Well, this is what I want. I want to eat lunch and I want to smoke a cigarette and I want to keep talking to myself for the next two thousand fucking miles..."! You should call your dad before it gets too late.
answer: I already did. This morning. When you went running.

question: Oh. You didn't tell me.
answer: I didn't know I had to.

question: Grace, look! Would you like to see that?
answer: I don't care.

question: I don't care. This'll be nice. We haven't seen any of the sights yet. It's history. When I was thirteen I used to love seeing things like this.
answer: You were never thirteen, Mom. Great idea. So now what?

question: How long is this going to go on?
answer: What?

question: You know what I mean? Is this it now? Is this the way we're going to be from now on? Do you want us to turn around and go back home? Do you?
answer: What are you asking me for? You didn't ask me if I wanted to come in the first place -- now I get to decide? Forget it!

question: Who do you think I'm doing this for? I'm doing this for you!
answer: Bullshit! It's about you! About you deciding! About you always being right! You always getting everything your way, controlling everybody -- like we work for you or something!

question: I don't believe this!
answer: You just want to get away from Daddy and you're using me to do it!

question: That's not true! Whatever problems your father and I are having, have nothing to do with this.
answer: You're amazing! You act like I don't live in that house! Don't you think I hear the two of you!? Don't you think I can tell what's going on? I'm not five years old, Mom! You want to divorce Daddy and Daddy doesn't want to.

question: Did he tell you that?
answer: He doesn't have to! It's, like, so obvious you can't stand him.

question: That's not true!
answer: Then why do you want to leave?

question: It's... it's not that simple to explain. I know you think it is, but it's not. The truth is, I don't really know what I want to do. I don't have all the answers.
answer: No, you just act like you do.

question: Yes. Fine. I'm sorry. I'm sorry... You buckled up? You cold?
answer: Little. Gee, this looks like a fun place.

question: Don't they believe in signs here?
answer: What would they say? "Ten miles to big rock." "Twenty miles to bigger rock."

question: There was supposed to be a turn off. Did I miss it?
answer: I didn't see it.

question: Can we take a look at Bronty's foal when we're done here, Dad?
answer: Sure. As long as she don't mind.

question: There's a kid at school says we should've imprint-trained him. He says if you do it soon as they're born, it makes them real easy to handle later on.
answer: That's what some folks say.

question: There was this thing on the TV about a guy who does it with geese. He has this airplane and these baby geese all grow up thinking it's their mom, and he flies it and they just follow. You hear 'bout that, Uncle T?
answer: Yeah, I hear about that.

question: Well, what do you think about that stuff?
answer: Well, Joe, I'll tell ya -- I don't know a whole lot about geese. Maybe it's okay for them to grow up thinking they're airplanes. But horses, as far as I can tell, can't fly.

question: We expecting company?
answer: I don't believe it.

question: Hello, Mr. Booker. Annie MacLean. From New York. We talked on the phone. It's, uh... beautiful country. I had a little bit of a hard time finding the place. There are no signs.
answer: Plenty of signs -- just none of them printed. Who do I get the idea you're not just passing through!

question: Well... OK... here it is... Uh... I'd like you to take a look at my horse. Now -- it won't take long and if, after that, you still don't feel...
answer: Were you thinking of personally driving me back East?

question: Oh no. She's here. I brought him along. And my daughter, too. We're staying at Peterson's...
answer: You mean you hauled him all the way out here? Just like that?

question: Well... yes... I had a trailer. It's not like I made him run along side of the car.
answer: All by yourself? I uh... ha, ha... I don't think I ever met a lady quite like yourself and I appreciate all the pains you've gone through to --

question: MOM! The door! Yeah?
answer: Uh, I'm Tom Booker. Your mother around?

question: She'll be right out. She's on the phone.
answer: First time in Montana? She gonna be long?

question: Probably. She's on the phone twenty- three hours a day.
answer: What does she do?

question: She's an editor.
answer: Mmm. An editor.

question: Sorry about that. Hi. Grace, this is Mr. Booker... Have you looked at Pilgrim?
answer: Uh, no. I was gonna take a look now.

question: You want us to come with you? I just have to run to the main house and give Mr. Peterson a check.
answer: Doesn't matter.

question: Grace?... Grace, you want to come with us, take a look at Pilgrim?
answer: Probably best she stays behind, anyway. Okay now... Okay now...

question: Well... You're closest anyone's gotten.
answer: I have to be honest. I still feel you made a long trip for nothing. But before I even think about it, I need to know something here and now. It's a question for Grace here. When I work with a horse, it's no good just me doing it. It doesn't work that way. The owner needs to be involved too.

question: Well, that'll be a little complicated --
answer: You can make it as complicated or as easy as you like. But she's the one who's gonna be riding him, am I right? So here's the deal. I'm not sure I can do anything, but I'm prepared to give it a go -- -- if you'll help. You have a problem with that?

question: Let's go see what's going on, then get something to eat.
answer: There's coffee inside... I was just bringing this to Tom.

question: Would you mind if I did? I'd like to talk to him.
answer: Sure. Does your daughter want to come inside?

question: Uh, no, we're going to dinner... Is this the way to the pasture?
answer: Pasture? Oh, that stretch of field near the hill? Yeah.

question: Hi.
answer: Hey... She sounds like she's doing all right. How is she?

question: Yeah. She seems to be getting more comfortable on the ranch, which is why I said yes to this move. But, whenever it's just the two of us, I don't know... Anyway... what's happening with the Delco lawsuit?
answer: Taking forever. I just got an additional list of sixty-two employees to interview before Monday. I don't know how I'm going to do it.

question: Well, it's good that you're there.
answer: So, how are you doing in Marlboro country? Is the magazine complaining at all?

question: Yeah, but nothing I can't handle. Lucy tells me she thinks Gottchalks's plotting, but what else is new.
answer: When are you coming home?

question: You know, I just asked that myself tonight. He doesn't know.
answer: Well then... maybe I will take some time... come visit.

question: Okay.
answer: I miss you, Annie.

question: I know. We miss you too.
answer: Good night.

question: Night.
answer: Did you ask him to come visit?

question: You already did.
answer: Did he mention it?

question: Yeah, he's going to think about it. You want me to pack for you?
answer: What we're doing here, Grace, is trying to get him to learn how to be a horse again. The others already know, see. That's how they are in the wild -- herd animals... ...When they've got a problem, like they have now with me and this flag, they look to each other. But old Pilgrim there has forgotten. I'm the rock and they're the hard place. He thinks he hasn't got a friend in the whole wild world... Hold this for a minute... Hold onto it, go on... We'll get there, Grace.

question: Grace? The clinic just called... They had to change your physical therapy appointment. We have to leave now.
answer: Hello, Annie...

question: Mr. Booker... You got everything you need?
answer: If I had everything I need, I wouldn't be going to physical therapy.

question: Honey, come on. Would you like to stay in town for dinner? Maybe see what movie's playing tonight?
answer: Why? There's no food in the house?

question: I'll drink to that... Where does this go, Diane?
answer: Oh, you can just set up on the dining table. I have to rearrange my shelves tomorrow.

question: Is this Mr. Booker? Tom's grandfather?
answer: Mm-mm. I never knew him. He died before Frank and I met. This here's... Frank and Tom's mother and father... there's little Frank and Tom...

question: She calls him Tommy...
answer: Always did. I think she favored him a little. You tend to when you have more than one, even though you love 'em all the same. Ha, she loves telling this story about how when he was two years old, he ran off. They found him in the barn, sleeping between two giant hooves of a Percheron stallion. She said that horse was protecting him and nobody could convince her otherwise.

question: I got a little confused though. The ranch Ellen was talking about -- that's not this one?
answer: No. See, Frank and Tom were raised near the Clark's Fork River, right between the Pryor and Beartooth Mountains. Beautiful piece of land. But they had this uncle Ned -- useless man, never interested in ranching. And when the grandparents died, he left for the city and sent word through lawyers he wanted his claim to the land so he could sell it. Three years of legation broke their father. Frank took it all in stride, but Tom... Tom loved that land. I don't think he ever got over it -- His home being sold out from under him. Seeing his father like that. Once he and Frank got their folks set up in a new place, Tom left... went off. We didn't see him for years...

question: All right, al right. Hold out your finger. The loop's knotted, right. Looks like the only way to take it off, is if we break our touch... Watch now... Oh, no. No, no. I only fall for that once. Go inside now before your mother starts hunting you down. Go on. So how was your first and last day of branding?
answer: Don't be so sure it's my last. There are a few people back home I'd like to put under a red hot iron.

question: You got too much sun today... Here...
answer: Thank you. What?

question: You ever just stand still for a minute?
answer: You stand still too long in New York you get hit by a bicycle messenger. You know, sometimes, I get the feeling, Mr. Booker, that you're laughing at me. Why is that? That's your cue to say you're not laughing at me.

question: Oh, I see, you write both sides of the conversation?
answer: It's a man's world, Mr. Booker. Most women have to.

question: Well, maybe I am laughing a bit... I just thought, as long as you're here, it would be nice for you to relax into the place a little.
answer: Well... It's beautiful country, I'll give you that. And I could see having some kind of vacation place. Retreat. But I don't know how you do it full time. Don't you miss the rest of the world?

question: What's that to miss?
answer: Ha... if you've never lived in a city with museums, theater, music, restaurants, uh... god, a million things, then it's something I can't explain.

question: Does Chicago count?
answer: You lived in Chicago?

question: When I was first married.
answer: You were married to a woman in Chicago?

question: I once heard Itzhak Perlman guest star with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. He played Rachmaninov's Vocalize Opus 34. No. 14. It was one of the most beautiful pieces of music I ever heard. I actually forgot where I was for a time. You seem surprised?
answer: Well, I, uh... you didn't...

question: Hello?
answer: I thought you guys were going to call me.

question: Oh, Robert, I'm sorry. We were so tired from the branding. Grace barely made it to her bed and I didn't have the energy to take my clothes off.
answer: Oh well... branding will do that to you.

question: Everything all right.
answer: Huh-huh. You?

question: Fine. Actually, today was a good day. You should have seen her.
answer: I wish I did. Well, uh the real reason I called, actually, was to tell you I saw Lucy at Jo-Jo's tonight and she seems very worried.

question: About what?
answer: Apparently, Gottschalk's been seen around town lunching with some very prominent magazine editors. Lucy said she tried to call you, but no one answered so she faxed you the list of names. She said one of them have contracts up fairly soon.

question: Oh. I didn't look at my faxes today. We left before sunrise.
answer: Honey, I hope you're not endangering your position. Listen, if you need to come back and you want me to come take over, for a while, I'll work it out. I mean, the firm's got other lawyers, but the magazine's got only one of you.

question: I've decided it's impossible to properly say hello in this place without a hat.
answer: A jogger, huh?

question: I don't jog, Mr. Booker. I run.
answer: Lucky for you. The grizzlies around here only go for joggers.

question: If I can survive rush hour, I figure I can handle grizzlies...
answer: You sleeping all right in that house?

question: I don't sleep all right anywhere. But the house is fine. Who's R.B.? I found this old cello case filled with bills and receipts.
answer: Sorry about that. I thought everything got cleared out. R.B. is my wife... ex-wife... Rachel. We used to live in that house together.

question: I thought you lived in Chicago?
answer: I thought you were an editor, not a reporter?

question: I have a way with animals.
answer: It's all right. He's young. Just hold out your hand a little lower so he can get the smell of you.

question: Oh yes. I forgot. He's beautiful.
answer: Why don't you ride anymore? Grace told me you used to ride when she was younger.

question: She did? I don't know, really. No time mostly. I thought it was supposed to be spring. Are you shy, Mr. Booker?
answer: Just polite. Well, maybe you'd like to try riding again, some time before you go home. Enjoy the day.

question: You too. Shit.
answer: Need a lift?

question: I can handle it! ... David, we've been behind a day or two before. But Lucy just Fedexed me all the material and it'll be approved by the end of the day. Oh, come on! This is such bullshit! The work is getting done, David. Lucky keeps me on top of everything.
answer: Lucy isn't you. We're losing something without you being here. Now, I know this is a rough time for you, but I think we should make another arrangement.

question: What the hell does that mean? How much more do I have to do to prove how important this magazine is to me?
answer: If this magazine is so important to you Annie, why are you in Montana? Look, this is what we're going to do. Finish up this issue. I'll set up a conference call in a few weeks. Just you, me and your lawyer and we'll just work this out so that everyone will be taken care of. Fair enough?

question: Uh, yes... Sure, David.
answer: All right. Speak to you then.

question: Come and take a ride with me. Can you drive?
answer: Drive? I'm not old enough yet.

question: It's never too soon to start.
answer: I can't...

question: I don't have all day. Put the key in and turn it. The right pedal is gas, the other one's the brake.
answer: I don't know if I can with my leg.

question: Well, there's only one way to find out. Give it a little gas. Well, we know you can. Now you just got to feel how much. Try it again. Nice, real nice. There's a little road down at the end here, turn onto it. Just follow this. Nothing to it. I'm going to shut my eyes here for a little while. Just keep going till you run out of road.
answer: I don't know if I can.

question: Where did you get Pilgrim from?
answer: We bought him in Kentucky. My mother and I took a trip down there to see him.

question: That must have been pretty special.
answer: Are you afraid of anything?

question: Getting old. Not being of much use, I guess. What went on out there, Grace? With Pilgrim? You see, Grace, I've got a problem. When I'm working with a horse, I like to know its history. Now, most times, the horse can tell you pretty much the whole story, but sometimes he can be so messed up in his head that you need more to go on. You need to know exactly what went wrong. Often times, it's the obvious thing, but something that went wrong just before that, maybe even some little thing... It's like if I'm driving and run into a tree. When somebody asks me, "Well, what happened?", I don't say, "Well, I plowed into a tree." I'd say, "The sun was in my eyes." or "I skidded." or "I took my mind off the road for a second." See what I mean? I don't know how you feel about talking about it and I can understand you might not want to. But if I'm going to figure out what's going on in his head, it'd sure help if I knew exactly what happened that day. Not today -- whenever you feel like it. I leave it up to you.
answer: Oh-oh. The answer's no.

question: You haven't heard the question yet. Truth is, you'd be doing me a favor. I got all these eager young colts need riding and poor old Rimrock here is feeling kind of left out...
answer: Poor thing.

question: He'd be grateful, he'd take real good care with you.
answer: Is this how you're going to make me pay my phone bill?

question: No, ma'am, I'm afraid that's extra. Relax our center... It's just sitting in a bucket.
answer: Yeah, it's been a while, but I... I remember the basic ideas...

question: OK. I'll stop talking then.
answer: Actually, I never rode Western. I'm sorry. Go ahead.

question: Well, he don't know that. Just sit the horse. Good... You have a nice seat.
answer: Thanks.

question: Feel good?
answer: Yeah.

question: It's a whole other world you have going on here. It just goes along, doing what it has to. And you're a part of it, you just wake up and, and there you are... And everything that seems like life or death some place else -- doesn't affect any of this one bit.
answer: Lift your leg.

question: How long did you live here with your wife?
answer: Five years. My son was born here.

question: Son?
answer: Yeah. I haven't seen him in a while. He used to come to the ranch over summers, but then he started having friends and was going off to college, so... Good boy. Hal. Lives in New York near his mom.

question: How did you meet her?
answer: College. In Illinois. She was playing the cello. I hadn't heard cello music growing up. She had the reddest hair, the bluest eyes. When she played, it was... She was the most beautiful thing I'd ever seen.

question: Why didn't it work out?
answer: She was never really happy here. She did the best she could. Grace told me you have a country house in Connecticut. Sounds like a beautiful place.

question: It is. It's lovely.
answer: Ever think of moving there full time?

question: We did at one point. When we thought we'd have more children. And we after tried. We tried everything, but... wasn't meant to be.
answer: I hear that! See, I knew she was never going to be a ranchest, but I wanted to try -- I thought maybe she'd give music lessons to the kids in town or at the school, maybe even recitals. My son would grow up here. Maybe have one or two more. I'd teach 'em what I could. They'd play with my brother's kids. All grow up together. And even if they all decided to go out into the world, they'd always know where home was -- cause we'd keep it for 'em...

question: That's very important to you, isn't it? Home.
answer: Yeah, I think it is. And I don't mean everybody's got to be married, have kids -- It's more like, knowing where you're from, where you belong, what feeds you, where you can go no matter what happens... Knowing what you're supposed to be doing while you're here.

question: How did you find out all that?
answer: I got lost.

question: Hi...
answer: Would you let me ride your horse?

question: Have you talked to Tom about it?
answer: Of course I have.

question: I don't know... You sure Tom said it's all right?
answer: Are you going to give me a hand or aren't you?

question: Honey, would you see if anybody wants -- You look really pretty.
answer: I thought there were too many forks on the table.

question: Well, one was for salad...
answer: Mom, they don't mind eating with one fork.

question: You're right. Good. Does anybody out there want something to drink?
answer: I'll take care of it.

question: Thanks, honey.
answer: Would anyone like something to drink?

question: SHIT!
answer: I'll give your mom a hand. Everything under control?

question: Not really. I'd forgotten how long it's been since I've done this. And I couldn't get any Parmesan cheese.
answer: Just make yourself comfortable.

question: I am comfortable.
answer: Ha, ha... all right, well, uh I guess you can bring out the pasta.

question: You missed a button.
answer: Huh?

question: Oh, I don't --
answer: It's okay. Grace, show them. I'm going to put the coffee on. I made an apple tart for dessert.

question: I'll help you with the coffee.
answer: Well... I know I should reject that offer, but I'm not going to.

question: No reason you should, no reason you should. I was looking in one of your magazines and saw that picture of the couple getting married at the Pyramids. Were you ever in Egypt?
answer: I was there for that shot, actually.

question: What was it like?
answer: Oh, God -- I think it was the fourth or fifth time I'd been there, so all I remember was the heat and how incompetent the photographer was... But, uh, Egypt is, well, it's like nothing else. It's like going back in time. I remember as a kid trying to imagine what a kid my age, centuries ago, walking over that same ground, was wondering about or, if they had the same problems as me... and I felt, connected to... to time itself, almost. Ha, I never realized how hard it was to describe.

question: I'd love to go there one time...
answer: You and Frank ever take a vacation?

question: You never let me have a turn!
answer: Don't be such a baby!

question: You just showing off for her!
answer: You shut up, stupid!

question: You're the one who's stupid -- letting her go and fall off your horse!!
answer: You little shit!

question: Grace? Is everything all right? Can we talk?
answer: About what?

question: Well... So you tried riding again?
answer: Yeah. Does that mean I'm cured?!

question: Honey, nobody's trying to cure you --
answer: ... You worried everything all right now and we'll have to go home?

question: What are you talking about?
answer: You... not wanting to go home because you hate daddy so much.

question: Grace, I don't hate your father.
answer: I can't remember the last time you made him dinner.

question: I was just trying to say thank you to Diane and Frank and --
answer: Tom?

question: Look, I just wanted to say, I think it's great you're riding again. And... and I think I know why you, you needed to do it alone... without anyone knowing...
answer: Yeah, you know everything!!

question: STOP IT! Why can't I talk to you!!
answer: NO, YOU STOP IT! Stop pretending like you care! Like this really isn't about you and Tom.

question: WHAT?! How can you -- I'm sorry if my friendship with Tom bothers you so much, but I happen to value having someone to talk to, especially when my own daughter ignores me night and day because no matter what I say, it's wrong and no matter what I do, it's wrong... I'm sorry I'm such a disappointment to you.
answer: Well, now you know what it feels like.

question: I don't deserve that. I have never looked at you as a disappointment. If I'm on your back to do better, if I push you to try harder it's because I want you to be the best you can be.
answer: FOR YOU! Because I'm your daughter which means you're the best mother! Isn't that what you're always talking about in interviews -- having it all, the great career, the great family... Proving everybody wrong. Wanting everybody to think you're this perfect woman!

question: Listen, if... if there's a part of you as parent that... that takes pride in your child -- that, you can look at them and see something you've accomplished as well... if that's wrong, then I'm sorry. But it wasn't my intention. I don't push for me. I do it for you... So you don't waste half your life feeling like you don't know where you belong.
answer: Yeah, well, you've done a great job.

question: Well, then I do apologize... But what I'm most sorry for is turning you into a spoiled brat who can only think about what she's feeling... who can't admit when she's wrong and who can't forgive when she's not.
answer: LEAVE ME ALONE!!

question: What did you say?
answer: I said... I started.

question: Started what?
answer: My period.

question: When? Tonight?
answer: I felt it happen downstairs and when I went into the bathroom. Who's going to want me now?

question: What?... Oh baby...
answer: Who's ever going to want me? Nobody will.

question: That's not true.
answer: Why should they?

question: Because you are... one of the most... incredible, bravest, most beautiful woman I have ever met. The efforts you make. Your courage and your dignity. I don't know where you got it? I honestly don't know how I would have handled all this if I were you.
answer: I'm sorry... about what I said. It's just that -- all those times you and Daddy were trying for another kid, I... I used to pray at night that it would work. And not because of you guys or that I wanted a brother or sister... but... just so I wouldn't have to be...

question: What?
answer: So special. Because I was the only one. You both wanted me to be so good at everything, so perfect and I wasn't. I was just me. And now I've completely ruined everything, anyway...

question: Sshhh... Ssshhhh... Hello? Yes. Oh. Oh, yes. One moment, please.
answer: Who is it?

question: Uh, nothing. I'm going to pick it up in the other room -- would you hang this up for me?
answer: Sure.

question: Okay, Grace... Operator?... I'm ready.
answer: I was waiting for you to come back.

question: I was waiting for you to come back.
answer: You hungry?

question: Judith was telling me about this boy she really liked. She never even had a chance to tell me his name... We were going to go around by the railroad bridge... We were laughing about something, I don't remember what. Her horse fell... ... Judith's foot was caught in the stirrup... she couldn't get up, she was so scared... I saw this truck, coming around the turn... ...He was honking, trying to get us to move... I tried to grab the reins to get Judith's horse out of the way... ...And the truck started skidding... ...It was coming right at us... There wasn't any time to do anything... It ran right into Judith's horse... ...Judith just disappeared... And it came right at Pilgrim and me... ...And Pilgrim reared up at the truck and I fell off... Judith... Oh God, Judith. I'm sorry...
answer: I won't tell you it'll stop feeling this bad... But I can tell you, you didn't do anything wrong... The same thing would have happened to me... or Frank... or Joe... And there's no sense in looking for a reason why things happen... I used to try and... always came up short. I don't think the why so's important as... what we do with what we get. I remember this boy I'd see up on the Blackfeet Reservation. He was sixteen. Great kid. Strong. He'd gone swimming and dived headfirst into a rock. Snapped his neck, paralyzed him... After the accident, I'd look in on him from time to time... and he wasn't there anymore. His mind, his spirit, whatever you want to call it, it just disappeared. And what was left was nothing but anger... It's like the boy I knew just went away somewhere...

question: I know where he goes.
answer: I know you do. Don't you disappear. You do whatever you have to, to hold on... I'll tell you one more thing... When Pilgrim reared up to face that truck... you know what I think?... I think that damn horse loved you so much, he was trying to protect you... That's what I think. Let me hold that...

question: I can't... not yet...
answer: There's no hurry. Take you time.

question: Must be nice for you to take a few days off from your work, huh?
answer: Well, I have more than a few days, ha, ha... I uh... I'm sort of... not an editor anymore... right now... First time I've said it out loud.

question: They fired you?
answer: No, it's more like a leave of- Ha, ha, ha. Yeah, they fired me.

question: You don't seem to upset?
answer: Delayed shock. Or maybe not. I know I could talk my way back if I wanted or... go to another magazine, someplace... Just not sure if I want to.

question: Guess you don't have to figure it out until you go home.
answer: Did you always know this was the life you wanted?

question: I fell in love. After that, I never thought about being anything but a rancher's wife. I never saw it like I was losing some other life, just felt like I was gaining one. I know that's not a popular opinion nowadays and I ain't saying it's the right one. We all have to find the life meant for us.
answer: Frank's a good man.

question: They don't come better. But I don't deny there are times I wonder about things I won't have. Maybe one day I'll get to see Egypt. Maybe not. But I know if you try too many different lives, you can wind up with no life at all...
answer: Sounds like something Tom would say.

question: Yes, it does.
answer: What?

question: Annie, I'm not good at this kind of talk -- goes round and round a thing but never comes to it -- so let's just say what it is. When you first came here, I didn't like you and I was worried. Tom means a lot to me and this family. Don't go looking here for whatever you looking for. Don't make that man go through something it took him a long time to see his way clear out of the first time.
answer: I don't think anybody can make Tom do anything he didn't want.

question: I can't believe it's the same horse.
answer: We still have a way to go.

question: How much longer do you think?
answer: Well, like I told your wife, it's really up to Pilgrim.

question: Tired? Small bed. Maybe I should sleep in the barn.
answer: You're allergic to hay.

question: I apologize for the surprise, but the days only opened yesterday and I figured...
answer: You don't have to explain. You have every right to come.

question: I can see why you put your faith in him. He's a genuine... good guy... Good at what he does. That's rare. You were right about coming here. I'm sorry for not thinking...
answer: No, it's okay. Believe me, there were plenty of times I didn't know what the hell was right.

question: How are you feeling about work?
answer: Let's not talk about that now.

question: There's still something going on inside of him I can't reach. So me and Smokey here, we're going to try laying him down. Okay?
answer: What does that mean?

question: It's more or less how it sounds. Sometimes it's not pretty to watch. Some horses fight it real hard. Your fella's already shown us he likes a good fight. So if you don't want to watch, I'll call you when it's done.
answer: I want to watch.

question: You got that soft rope?
answer: What is he doing this?

question: Grace, I need you to come with me.
answer: No, you're only going to hurt him some more.

question: He's not hurt. He's okay. Look at him.
answer: No!

question: Grace, Listen... you've got to do this. Just trust me one more time.
answer: Do what?

question: Ah... Now, are you sure you want to drive that horse back yourself? There are plenty of people 'round here who do that sort of thing.
answer: I already know the way... and it's not like I have a job I have to rush home for. Between you and me, I could use the time alone.

question: And you'll be all right by yourself here, after they've gone?
answer: It's just one night. If I get uncomfortable, I'll go over to Hanks.

question: Promise?
answer: Promise.

question: Good luck to you, Annie.
answer: You too, Diane.

question: Are you going to stay in the city or go up to Connecticut?
answer: Connecticut. I told the office I'd work out of there next week. When are you planning to start back?

question: Probably first thing in the morning. It's too late to start now. I'm going to try not to do too much driving in the dark.
answer: May I have a suggestion?

question: Yeah, what?
answer: Take your time.

question: What do you mean? You look like something's wrong.
answer: I'll tell you something, Annie -- I stood there looking at what was happening to that horse... And, I swear, it felt like the same thing was happening to me.

question: I don't understa-
answer: And I have two choices. I can either fight the way things are, or accept them. See, I always knew I loved you more. Didn't bother me. I always felt lucky... a little amazed... that such a vibrant, beautiful woman would want to be with a man like me... And I guess I thought as long as I did everything right -- if I was the best husband I could be, the best father... even being a good lawyer only mattered to me because of what it meant for us... if I could do all that, it wouldn't make any difference if we loved each other the same or not... I wasn't asking for more. I told myself I didn't need more. But you don't know how you feel about me. You don't know... if you want a life with me anymore... And I don't want you to come home until you do know... ... one way or the other.

question: Show me again.
answer: Annie!

question: One more time.
answer: Summers are short here, Annie. There isn't much of a fall. Before you know it, the roads are closed... the nights get long.

question: I don't care! We'd be together.
answer: Two people can't just be alone together in the world. At least not us...

question: I won't.
answer: I figured, whenever you decided to go, you'd be all set.

question: How thoughtful of you. And what if I decide not to go? Leave me alone!
answer: Annie, please...

question: NO!... NO!... YOU DON'T DECIDE THIS!... NO!...
answer: I don't know any other way, Annie.

question: Why?
answer: You think this is easy for me!? It's just happened this way sometimes. I can't explain it. But I look at you and see Grace and I see Robert, and no matter what you decide about him, I just know this is right. Your life isn't here and you know it.

question: Then what have we been doing? I mean what was the point?
answer: The point was to love each other.

question: Why?
answer: Because we had to... And I'll never stop loving you, Annie. Here. Where my life is. Annie... Annie?

question: Can we go for one more ride?
answer: Sure. I'll saddle them up.

question: Yes?
answer: Hi. Um, there doesn't seem to be any hotel room available and someone told me to come here and ask for "Tubab" who might to have a place for me to stay. Are you "Tubab"?

question: No. I am a "tubab."
answer: What do you mean?

question: Tubab means white man.
answer: Oh, I miss you. You look beautiful.

question: Oh, I miss you. You look beautiful.
answer: So do you.

question: How's everything?
answer: Good.
